answers.answer: I realized your asking for others who have dealt with this, I have not but you just educated me on this illness...and I am sorry. It looks like none of the medications are without risk. From having a dog with a quick killing cancer, learn what the outcome will be, life span etc. I know you love your dog, just know these answers and know what your willing to go through emotionaly and what is best for your dog. I kept my dog a live for 6 months because I was not ready to let him go. It was the best decision for me, but it was also painful for me always knowing that soon I was going to have to stop the treatment and let him go. With Cushings, it might be that you can treat this conditon and your dog will be fine for several years...I hope this is the case. I kept another dog around that almost died on me three years ago, cost me a lot of money, and she still does as she is always getting ill. I love her and keep doing what I feel is best. Good luck with this and I am sorry that your having to go through all of this.

Thank you so  much for responding. I appreciate the support. My vet tells me the lifespan for my dog is 18-24 months and that the meds won't extend her life but will improve the quality of her life. I guess I just wanted to know if the experience of other owners confirmed this. Maybe I also wanted someone to say their dog did great and lived for years! Right now she is happy and playful and enjoying her life. I hope that doesn't change for a long time. Thanks again.

My only suggestion to you is make sure your vet is familuar with Vetoryl.  Ours wasn't, he knew more about the other med for cushings.  He didn't take the proper tests during the time she was on the meds, and her levels were all screwed up.  Its difficult to control it from the beginning, but I feel with the right vet you have a chance.  Definately try, you never will know what will happen unless  you do, and you won't regret having given it your best shot.  Enjoy every day with her, and spoil her.

Good advice. As far as I can tell, the vet seems knowledgable. She told me the risks and benefits. She told me not to start the meds until Friday after Thanksgiving because there is the  risk of a crisis up to day 10 and she did not want that to happen on a holiday. She told me to bring Jesse back on day ten for more ACTH levels. She also gave me a supply of prednisone and told me the symptoms to watch out for--that would indicate her  cortisol bottoming out--and to stop the Vetoryl, give the prednisone, and  call the on-call vet at once. Jesse is 58 pounds, and she is starting with a lower than recommended dose of 30 mg daily in order to try to avoid some side effects. You are exactly right--I won't regret giving it my best shot. I want to know I did everything I could for her. Thanks for your reply.

Your vet seems to be really knowledgeable about Cushings, thats great. Ours started on 30mg for a 25 lb dog, and never retested her, I had to call and tell him to after two months, and by then she needed the prednisone.  He had to read the instructions on the meds to find out what to do, he had no clue.  Good Luck with Jesse, she sounds like shes in good hands, yours and the vets.

Thanks for your reassurance. It helps me know my faith in my vet is justified. Before I switched to her I had a vet I had to beg to do anything beyond annual vaccinations. I had to diagnose Jesse's hypothyroidism from researching the internet and got him to do the lab test by sitting in the exam room and refusing to leave until he drew the sample. Oddly enough, the result was almost at panic value. After he ignored my dachshund's heart murmur until she was in end stage heart failure and she died in my  lap while driving to the emergency clinic I decided I had to make a change. So I certainly understand your frustration with your vet. Thank you so much for taking the time to send the supportive comments. Jesse's first dose is 3 days away and I will keep you posted.

I was looking back over your posts and you are such a wonderful support to so many. I am so sorry about Mollie. It must be tough to stay in touch with other owners after losing your dog to the same illness, so  that makes me appreciate your help to me even more.

Thanks for your comment, it was very hard to lose Mollie, only for the fact I think she could have done better, longer, with the proper care. We knew there was no cure, but we hoped to extend her life, just as you are with Jesse.I You seem to keep very informed on your pets care,which is good, we trusted our vet was, and found out the hard way cheaper isn't always better.  Whenever something major happens to one of our animals in the future, we are going to an animal hospital that has expert vets for each type of disease.  You pay more, but at least will have the peace of mind knowing your pet is getting the best care possible, and in the long run it might be cheaper getting the right treatment the first time instead of going back again and again, playing a guessing game.  Please let me know how shes doing on her meds, I hope you get at least a couple of more years out of your little girl, spoil her rotten.

Thanks so much. Jesse has been outside running and playing with her stuffed toys just like a pup today. She is so happy and attentive to me tonight. Tomorrow morning is her first dose and I am so fearful this will be the last day she does any of those things. I hope I am overreacting, and that she just sails through her treatment unfazed. Thank you for all your kind words and thoughts.
I misquoted the Vetoryl dosage. It is 60 mg which is half the insert's recommendation of 120 mg. I need to look things up before I start quoting!
What are Jesse's symptoms?  Did your vet comment on how long it would take to see any improvement?

Thanks so much for the reply.  Jesse's symptoms: polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, potbelly, multiple benign lipomas, panting, recent UTI, and numerous small, hard, keratinized growths all over. I know there is a technical term for these but I have forgotten it. She has not lost any hair yet but her elbows have always been calloused. She has history of elevated liver enzymes, hypothoyroidism, and hypertension. Behaviorally she has always been thunderstorm-phobic. She has always been easily excitable. This has caused some pack-management issues but I don't want to get into that now. But it was those behavioral issues that prompted her first ACTH challenge 2 years ago. She had urinalysis with her recent tests and the specific gravity revealed she was not concentrating her urine. She has also had ACTH challenge and LDDS. I don't have any of these specific values but I know my vet would be happy to give them to me. We have not done an abdominal ultrasound yet.Again, thank you so much for your help.

Did anything show up on her ACTH test that she had two years ago?  I am very impressed on how thorough your vet is, he/she seems to really try to find out what the problem is instead of waiting and guessing.  Thats great.

Her ACTH 2 years ago was normal. This time it was very nearly normal but double what it was before. Her liver enzymes doubled too. The doc told me the ACTH has such a high false negative rate that it could not reliably predict Cushing's. That is why we did LDDS which definitely showed pituitary Cushing's. The vet is great--she has been in practice about 30 years and when her daughter went off to college at Texas A & M she went with her and did some additional study in internal medicine and surgery. She is great to sit down and explain things and is always available for questions. She is my third vet and I feel fortunate to have been referred to her.She couldn't say how soon we would see improvements in Jesse. I feel very comfortable with the instructions she gave me for the Vetoryl loading and I am just thrilled you also have confidence in hter.

I think the big difference is that she was willing to go back to school and learn about new improvements in meds, etc.  Mine preferred to read the back of the pill package.  Keeping my fingers crossed that you have good results.

I have had 3 dogs with cushings.  The first dog, Peanut, who was 13, had cushings for several years before he passed away 3-1/2 years ago.  He had a very complicated medical history with COPD, grade 4 heart murmur, throid issues and several other ailments.  His vet chose not to treat his cushings with any medication other than for me to take as good of care of him as I could.  The last 5 weeks he developed diabetes.  We could not stabilize the diabetes/insulin dosage due to all the other medications he took.  He died in my arms of a heart attack while at the vets during rehydration for his diabetes - all this was 5 months before Vetoryl was approved in the USA.  I believe he would have lived longer had Vetoryl been available.In 2010 my elderly chihuahua, Boots, was diagnosed with both cushings and diabetes.  By this time Vetoryl had been approved for use in the US. Boots was tested and put on insulin shots 2x a day and then in a week on Vetoryl, 30 mg.  The Vetoryl has made a world of difference in him.  He acts like a younger dog.  You'd never know he was so ill when he was diagnosed with diabetes and cushings.  Vetoryl has not given him any side effects and it's been a miracle drug for him.This week my 10 year old pomeranian, Sassy, was diagnosed with cushings.  She has an extremely complicated medical history with COPD, grade 4 heart murmur, thyroid and liver issues, as well as a pinched nerve in her neck rendering her unable to completely control her front legs in trying to walk.  She does limp slowly around and is not in leg or nerve pain.   She takes 4-5 pills 2 times a day for her liver, heart, a water pill, throid, etc and she took Vetoryl, 30 mg, tonight for the first time.  I expect to see marked improvement in her within two weeks.  Vetoryl is not cheap; I pay $1.85 per pill - but my dogs have been faithful loving companions and I will do whatever I need to for their health as long as they have good quality of life.I highly recommend you try Vetoryl for your dogs cushings.  There is at least one other pill out there - I have seen it for $7 per pill and you give it once a week.  However Vetoryl is recommended by my vet and Boots has shown remarkable improvement on it and I am expecting the same results with Sassy within the next 2 weeks as the dosage loads into her body.

You've really had some major problems with your dogs, it is really good to hear that you've had good results with Vetoryl.  Your dogs are very lucky to have such a devoted owner, and I hope Boots and Sassy continue to improve so you can enjoy them much longer.
Do you have an update? I'm in the same boat. I just gave my dachshund her first dose, and started reading Things online- and I am now freaking out!

Don't freak out! My Jesse did great on the Vetoryl--never had any side effects and her troubling symptoms went away almost immediately.You should get involved in this community--they are very supportive and knowledgable--anything I know about Cushing's I learned here.http://www.k9cushings.com/forum/Good luck!!

question: My 11 year old english coonhound has been diagnoed with pituitary-type cushing's and is about to start Vetoryl. I am just wanting to know of other owner's experiences with this particular drug. What I have read on this site so far seems pretty hopeless.
title: vetoryl
